what's the longest surgery you;ve ever taken part in? Well, I've been in on a few surgeries, but the longest one I think was a 10-hour procedure. Hello what did you think about the articlee? I thought it was really eye-opening and disturbing at the same time. The fact that Shelton and his brothers had to go through the foster care system and then end up in prison is heartbreaking. It's crazy to think that the system was supposed to help them but ultimately failed them. Definitely. I felt so bad for the children at first. Me too, it's just heartbreaking to see how the system failed them, especially when they were just kids. And then to see how it's connected to the prison system is just wild.

They should be in school and making friends! I know, it's just unbelievable. The fact that Shelton was in and out of foster homes and prisons by the time he was 18 is just staggering. And now he's turned his life around and is working to help others who have gone through similar experiences. I had a cousin who went to jail at a young age, he never really changed. I think it's a little different when you're a kid. I mean, Shelton's story is just so tragic, but it's also inspiring because he's turned his life around and is now helping others. He's using his pain to heal others, which I think is really admirable.

I definitely believe that people can't really change. what about you? I think it's hard to say, but it seems like Shelton has definitely made an effort to change and is now helping others, so maybe it's possible. It's also interesting that he says his experiences are what allow him to connect with others and help them, which suggests that even though the system failed him, he's still been able to find a way to use his pain for good. Maybe my cousin is just a sociopath. I hope those kids that got out find good jobs in the future. Yeah, that's possible, but it's also possible that he's been through a lot and hasn't had the support system to help him turn his life around. I think Shelton's story is a good example of how people can be resilient and turn their lives around, even after experiencing trauma and adversity.

I think that if i owned a business, i would definitely think twice about a person who served time Yeah, I can understand that, it's definitely a red flag. But Shelton's story is a good example of how people can change and turn their lives around, even after being in prison. He's not just using his past as an excuse, he's actually using it to help others and make a positive impact. How would you feel about someone in your family marrying a person that went to jail before? That's a tough question. I think it would depend on the individual and their circumstances. If the person has genuinely turned their life around and is working to make positive changes, I think it's possible to see them as a good partner. However, if they're still struggling with the same issues that led them to jail, it might be more challenging to support their relationship. Shelton's story is interesting because he's able to connect with others who have gone through similar experiences, but at the same What if it's minor like stealing, but has done it many times. I think that's still a concern, but maybe not as much as someone who has committed more serious crimes. The thing is, if Shelton had just been in and out of jail for minor crimes, he wouldn't have had the same kind of life experience that he did, which ultimately helped him turn his life around and start helping others. Very interesting! Well it was nice talking to you! bye Likewise, it was a good conversation.

well, yes and no.  we all have personal responsibility for our choices in my opinion.  regardless of circumstance But how can you say that when the brothers' choices were heavily influenced by their environment and their experiences? Shelton says himself that the foster-care system and the penal system perpetuated a cycle of trauma and hurt, and that it's hard for someone to escape that cycle when they're struggling with their own pain and instability. yes they definitely did, it failed them I know, it's like they were stuck in this never-ending cycle of pain and hurt, and it's amazing that Shelton has been able to turn his life around and now helps others who are going through similar struggles. He's a great example of how people can heal and move forward, even in the face of adversity.

yes that was the best part of the article It really was, it's amazing to see how Shelton has turned his life around and is now helping others. yes it needs help, but i think there is a lack of good foster parents I agree, it's not just about the system, it's about the people who are supposed to be helping these kids. Yes, and this was a pretty amazing, sad story with a good ending.  well I must go, have a good day.  goodbye It was great talking to you about this article.  Have a great day too.

What a story! I know, right? It's like a tragic tale of a family torn apart by the system. The brothers' experiences are heartbreaking, and it's amazing to see how their lives have turned out. Shelton's determination to help others who've gone through similar struggles is really inspiring. It sounds like the system failed him at an early age That's an understatement. The system failed him in so many ways, and it's clear that it had a lasting impact on his life. His experiences in the foster-care system and the prison system are a stark reminder of how broken the system can be.

For sure. Many fall  through the cracks and its so sad. It's like, the system is designed to perpetuate a cycle of failure, rather than helping people succeed. I know! What are the odds? I know, it's staggering. And it's not just Shelton's story, it's so many others like him. The system seems to be designed to keep people stuck in a cycle of poverty and trauma.

I'd say have more oversight of individual cases. So many children arent getting the attention on their cases that they need. Do you have any suggestions? I think that's a great point. One thing that comes to mind is that the system needs to prioritize family reunification. If a child is removed from their home, the goal should be to reunite them with their family as soon as possible. But as Shelton's story shows, that's not always the case. It's like, if his mother was receiving the help she needed, maybe the brothers wouldn't have been removed from the home in the first place. Absolutely. And also some sort of self sufficiency classes for those who are about to age out of the system That's a great idea! Teaching them life skills and giving them a sense of purpose and direction could really make a difference in their lives. It's amazing how something like that could help them break the cycle of poverty and trauma.

My school had them every week and I loved it. Learned a lot of life skills Yeah, it's great to have programs that focus on teaching life skills and helping people become more independent. It's a vital part of breaking the cycle of poverty and trauma. Sewing, vehicle maintenance, budgeting, childcare, basic home repairs, tax basics, etc. Those are all great ideas! Teaching people how to manage their finances, maintain a home, and take care of themselves and their families can be so empowering. I think it's especially important for people who are aging out of the system, as they'll be facing a lot of challenges and will need to know how to navigate the world on their own.

I think all schools should offer classes like that. Theyre very beneficial I completely agree. It's amazing how much of a difference it can make in someone's life. I think its amazing how he turned his life around. A true inspiration He is, and his story highlights the importance of supporting people who have been through similar experiences. His work with recently released inmates and families who have lost their children to the system is really impactful. Great talking to you. Goodbye Same to you. It was great discussing this article with you. The system really needs to be reformed to help people like Shelton and his brothers.

Hello. The situation in India is really terrible I know, it's heartbreaking to see what's happening. The impact of coal mining on people's health and the environment is just devastating. Did you know that in Chhattisgarh, fly ash has caused serious respiratory problems and illnesses like tuberculosis? Apparently. The most worrisome part of the situation is the fact that they barely compensate the victims It's not just the compensation, the entire process of displacement and environmental degradation is just brutal. I mean, people are losing their homes and livelihoods, and the environment is suffering.

Indeed. What do you think can be done on the part of the citizens in order to draw attention of the international communities? I think a lot can be done through social media and awareness campaigns. We can share stories and photos like the ones taken by Subrata Biswas to highlight the reality on the ground. This can put pressure on the government to take action and also raise awareness among the general public about the issue. In all honesty, I have no idea. I'm not surprised. The situation is complex and the government seems to be turning a blind eye to the problem. But I think if more people start talking about it, it could bring attention to the issue and force some changes.

It's left for their government to decide But that's the problem, the government seems to be more concerned with the economic benefits of coal mining than the welfare of the people and the environment. True. It's really pathetic The compensation is often too little, too late. I mean, 10,000 rupees for a damaged house and medical care? It's almost an insult.

Nope. I doubt if the government will allow that. That's what's worrying. The government seems to be more interested in the profits from coal mining than in taking responsibility for the devastating impact it's having on the people and the environment. The government in India is corrupt. They are involved in the illegal trade of ivory. They won't allow any external body to interfere with their business The corruption runs deep, doesn't it? It's not just the government, but also the companies involved in coal mining who are more interested in profits than in the welfare of the people and the environment. They're causing irreparable damage to the land and the wildlife, and the government seems to be turning a blind eye to it all.

I've read series of disturbing stories about their activities in the illegal trade of ivory Yes, it's a big concern and one that's closely linked to the corruption in the government. They're more interested in lining their pockets than in doing what's right for the people and the environment. Yeah. It's all about the rupees Exactly, the economic benefits seem to be the only thing that matters to them. The people and the environment are just collateral damage.

That's the reality. The reality is harsh and devastating, and it's hard to imagine how people are coping with it. The article mentions that in Dharamjaigarh, the most affected area, officials have recorded 30 elephant and 75 human deaths so far. That's just heartbreaking. That won't be a bad idea. How do "we" go about that We could start by sharing stories and photos from the article on social media, that way we can reach a wider audience and raise awareness about the issue.

There have been several scam cases with GFM It's a shame, the government and companies involved in coal mining seem to be more interested in lining their pockets than in taking responsibility for the devastating impact it's having on the people and the environment. That'll be great I'm glad you think so. We can start by sharing the photos and stories of people who have been affected by coal mining in India. The one of Kanti Bai Sau, who lost her home and farm to an open-cast coal mine, is particularly striking. Her son died last year of respiratory complications and she was promised compensation but never received it. It's heartbreaking to think that she's not alone in her struggles. goodbye It's been a long conversation, but I'm glad we could discuss the issue of coal mining in India and the devastating impact it's having on the people and the environment. I hope that by raising awareness, we can bring about some change.

The effect is terrible I know, it's heartbreaking to think about all the suffering and harm caused by the coal industry. The fact that people are living in an environment with fly ash everywhere, it's like they're being poisoned. I think humans are generally selfish Yes, it's a classic case of prioritizing economic gains over people's health and the environment. The coal industry is a huge contributor to the state's economy, but at what cost?

Yea, It is sad and pathetic. It really is. The residents of these villages are already struggling to make ends meet, and then they're forced to deal with the health consequences of living near the coal mines. Yea, the pollution is massive. And it's not just the people who are suffering, the elephants are also being forced to leave their natural habitats and enter villages in search of food, leading to conflicts between humans and elephants.

I dont see that happening sincerely. The are rich, they can afford moving to another planet! But the thing is, they're not just harming the environment and the animals, but also the people living in those areas are struggling to make ends meet and are being compensated very little for their losses. For example, Rujri Khalkho received only 10,000 rupees to repair her house and pay for her medical care after her home was damaged by elephants. That is what they do. They give false hopes They promise the villagers that they'll be relocated or compensated, but it's just empty promises, like what happened to Kanti Bai Sau. She was promised 200,000 rupees and a job, but she received nothing.

People should be more orientated. Toward the well-being of the environment and the people living in those areas, not just their own profits. It's disheartening to see that the coal industry is more concerned with its own interests than the lives of the people affected by it. Oh, that is great. Reforestation is a great way...I hope people follow it through But even reforestation efforts might not be enough to solve the problem, considering the scale of the destruction caused by coal mining. The fact that officials estimate 50 million tonnes of fly ash is generated each year in Chhattisgarh, but only half of it is being reutilized, is alarming.

Yea, that is some nice method. It's not just a method, it's a necessity. Reusing the fly ash can help reduce the pollution and mitigate some of the harm caused by the coal industry. But it seems like a drop in the ocean compared to the massive scale of the problem. yes...I think finding alternatives to coal is also a great idea But it's easier said than done, considering the economic interests at play. The coal industry is a huge contributor to India's economy, and transitioning to alternative energy sources would require significant investments and infrastructure changes.

And nuclear sources.. But that's not without its own risks, isn't it? It is good I think. And necessary. The people in these villages need help, and it's not just about providing compensation, but also about addressing the root causes of the problem. Yes. can we exchange our byes? But isn't it too little, too late for the people who are already suffering from the effects of the coal industry? good. I have few minutes left here. bye bye, it was nice having this conversation with you. I hope we can talk about this issue again sometime.

Yeah. It's bad enough when things like this affect people actually involved, but when you have people getting hurt that weren't even part of it it's just so much worse. It's a ripple effect, right? The damage from coal mining isn't just limited to the people directly affected by it, but also to the community as a whole. As a smoker myself, I felt the need to parley with the author of the article. A smoker's perspective can be valuable in this conversation. What's your initial reaction to the proposal of banning smoking in parks and playgrounds? Frankly, I enjoy the fact that the space is dwindling. Smoking is more than a nicotine fix for me. It also gives me an excuse and an opportunity to get away from other people for a while. The only time it really bothers me is when I've got a flight with connections. I can understand that. Having a smoke break can be a nice way to take a break from the hustle and bustle of daily life. But don't you think that children learning that smoking is normal is a concern?

The government dictates a lot of what people can and can't do in public. I'm assuming you don't smoke. Are you bothered by seeing/smelling people smoke in public? I am. It can be unpleasant, especially when it's in close proximity to non-smokers or in enclosed areas. But I'm not sure if banning smoking in parks and playgrounds is the solution. It may not be an apt analogy, but I equate smoking in public to open carry. I'm not comfortable with seeing a person holding a gun on their hip, it makes me nervous for my health and the health of those around me. But, people are allowed to do it and I just keep my distance. That's a valid point. Just as you might feel uneasy around someone openly carrying a gun, some people might feel uneasy around smokers in public spaces. However, with smoking, it's not just about the immediate health effects, but also the potential long-term effects of normalizing smoking behavior in children. Do you think the benefits of having a smoke-free environment for children outweigh the benefits of allowing smokers to have a break in a public park?

Planes, schools, hospitals... I'm trying to think of another behavior that has been similarly restricted but i'm coming up short. It's interesting that you bring up those examples.
